caption.title: Speed of epidemic introduction and outward transmission correlate and increase with strength.
caption.p: For each urban location in one of our two data sets, we estimate the speed of an outward transmission (x-axes) following an introduction into that location until 10% of locations experience outbreaks. We average this value over different runs of the epidemic simulations for each of the 28 different introduction times. The speed of introduction (y-axes) is estimated by the time since the introduction in another location until the focal location receives its first infection, averaged over all introduction location-time combinations. Colors correspond the strength (total mobility flow in and out from a location over seven days). All these simulations assume an initial outbreak of no circadian effect and R 0 = 1.5. For the Yushu City data of panel (a), the inward and outward transmission speeds, χ and Γ 10%, are correlated with a Pearson’s correlation coefficient of 0.83, and the speeds correlate to strength with coefficients of −0.85 and −0.75, respectively.
